sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: HIV infection, receiving anti-retroviral therapy - Non-infective diarrhea: 125 mg ORALLY twice daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients.

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: CD4 cell count/viral load: no dose adjustment recommended

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
HIV infection, receiving anti-retroviral therapy - Non-infective diarrhea

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• infectious etiology of diarrhea; risk of worsening infection; rule out before initiating therapy
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Flatulence (3.1%)
  • Hepatic:Increased bilirubin level (3.1%)
  • Respiratory:Bronchitis (3.9%), Cough (3.5%), Upper respiratory infection (5.7%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastroenteritis (1% to 2%)
  • Hematologic:Decreased white blood cell count (1% to 2%)
  • Immunologic:Herpes zoster (1% to 2%)
  • Renal:Increased frequency of urination (1% to 2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Crofelemer inhibits chloride ion channels that regulate chloride ion and fluid secretion by intestinal epithelial cells, resulting in a blockade of chloride ion secretion and the associated high volume water loss in diarrhea.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Bioavailability, oral: minimal
  • Effects of food: no effect on systemic exposure

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • take with or without food
  • swallow whole; do not crush or chew

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: reduced frequency of loose stools associated with HIV/AIDs may indicate efficacy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: This drug may cause upper respiratory tract infection, bronchitis, cough, or flatulence.
